justification: The study investigates choice-price preference reversals by manipulating response formats within subjects using binary choice and willingness-to-pay (WTP) judgments, showing consistent differences in preferences between the two methods.
The hyperbolic discounting model was fitted to choice and pricing data, with the model indicating significantly different discounting rates depending on whether choice or pricing data were analyzed.
Choice impulsivity is assessed through binary choice trials where participants generally favor the smaller-sooner (SS) option over the larger-later (LL) option.
An adapted version of the price accumulation model was used to account for systematic choice-price preference reversals by incorporating the anchoring effects of payoffs and delays.
